text: What I meant to say is that tail hedging should not be taking strong directional views on the market. If it were, you don't need to tail hedge. You just take that view. If you think the market's coming off tomorrow, dump your longs and go short if your conviction's high enough. Tail hedging isn't really supposed to do that. So what can it be if it isn't that? That's the question I'm trying to grapple with. Now, if it isn't that, and it's just going out and buying a put, 15% out of the money put once a quarter and then rolling it, which is a piece maybe at the JP Morgan thing, roughly, I don't see great value in that either. Unless, of course, you're doing things that have great value aside from the puts, in which case you can eat the cost or the implied negative alpha doing that as an offset to the stuff you're doing that's very good. And I know they pick stocks within that. If you're doing that in a program, I don't wish to give them any disrespect. But if you only took that leg, there's no value in that. You, Corey, sitting at your desk or me sitting in my chair, what are we adding? Well, we need to figure out ways to protect the downside as efficiently as possible, given the current state of the world. That's where the bag of tricks come in. I could put on any number of hedges at any given point in time. I could buy a one-day-to-maturity put. I could buy a one-day-to-maturity out-of-the-money put. I could buy a put spread. I could buy a put butterfly. I could, this is just in the S&P. I could buy a straddle and hedge it. I could buy an in-the-money option and hedge it. If I'm trying to make bets on realized volatility, vis-a-vis what I paid for the option, I can go long-dated. I can play the call side to get bounded gains with maybe some edge. There are all sorts of things I can do. And across the board, I can do that. And across markets, I can do many, many more things. The bag of tricks idea is where do I think the surface should be priced? Where has it been priced? And where's the value? There's always value somewhere in the surface, or at least there's egregious overvaluation somewhere in the surface. And so you sell a bit of that and you buy quite a bit more of other stuff to hedge. So the bag of tricks is simply that. It's what's the best hedge given today's environment. Now, in the first book, The Second Leg Down, I use the well-worn phrase, every dog has its day. And I figured this out when I started backtesting option strategies. There was some scenario for any option strategy, even the silliest one, that pays out pretty nicely. Looks good. And even the best strategy has stuff that doesn't work well. So I started thinking, well, option strategies have to be regime dependent. So let's give you the simplest decision tree. Buy a put, buy a put spread, buy a put butterfly, S&P 500. Bam. What are the conditions in which I would do A versus B versus C? That's the bag of tricks approach. I'm going to figure out what I can do. It might not be the be all and end all. If I buy a put spread instead of an outright put one to one, same size, obviously I won't make as much in a crash, but it might be cheaper. It might be worth the trade off. Maybe I can widen the strikes. Make it look better. If the skew is steep, maybe I can do more. And one thing that a lot of people don't understand, maybe they do, but I'm being presumptuous, is that payout ratios can sometimes go up when you trade a spread. And I don't just mean buying a butterfly and praying that it will land at maturity at the peak. I'm not referring to that. And the brokers love to sell stuff like that. You could make 20 to one on this thing and it costs you very little. But of course you need to hold to maturity and absorb the gamma risk with the day to go. And sweat over it to get that payout. Not really speaking of that. I'm more speaking of trades where you can do more units if you try to spread instead of just buying a put outright. You just cut the premium costs to the point where for a fixed budget, you can just do it a heck of a lot more.
